titlestmt.titleproper: Inventory of the Frank R. Rapsilber Papers, 1938-1963

publicationstmt.publisher: University of Wyoming. American Heritage Center.

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Leslie Waggener. 2018

did.head: Collection Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: University of Wyoming. American Heritage Center.

did.abstract: Papers of a pilot and professional aircraft communicator with the Civil Aeronautics Authority.

bioghist.head: Biography of Frank R. Rapsilber
bioghist.p: Frank R. Rapsilber (b. 1908) was a pilot and a professional aircraft communicator with the Civil Aeronautics Authority. After high school, Rapsilber began training at the U.S. Naval Training Station at Great Lakes, Illinois where he took a competitive test and was selected for the Navy’s radio school in San Diego, California. After completing the course, he was assigned to the cruiser U.S.S. Omaha and then to the staff of the Navy Unit, Commander Destroyers, Battle Force. Rapsilber was discharged from the Navy in 1933 after six years of service. He next served with the U.S. War Department’s Bureau of Engineers as a communications specialist for the Dundee, a hydraulic dredge boat. In 1936, Rapsilber transferred to the relatively new Bureau of Air Commerce, which became the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) in 1940, and then the Federal Aviation Agency in 1958. Rapsilber began as a Junior Radio Operator with the Bureau of Air Commerce stationed in Peoria, Illinois, and was promoted in two years to Assistant Radio Operator, transferring to St. Louis, Missouri. In 1941, Rapsilber became a watch supervisor at a CAA station in Denver, Colorado. In 1942, he was assistant chief of a CAA station in Wichita, Kansas, and, when that station closed, became in 1944 the chief of a CAA station in Dodge City, Kansas. He spent the rest of his career in Dodge City and retired from the Federal Aviation Agency in 1963.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection contains official correspondence and memos, mostly orders related to Rapsilber’s aviation career, but also memos regarding CAA policy (1938-1963); articles on aviation, including several by Rapsilber; newspaper clippings regarding aviation; Rapsilber’s pilot log book; and maps and aeronautical charts. There are Civil Aeronautics Authority property certificates; issues of CAA Memo (1953-1958) and Fly By (1961); and Rapsilber’s travel vouchers. Also included are photographs of the Dodge City, Kansas, airport and the 1957 snow storm.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: There are no access restrictions on the materials for research purposes, and the collection is open to the public.

userestrict.head: Copyright Information
userestrict.p: The researcher assumes full responsibility for observing all copyright, property, and libel laws as they apply.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: There are no known other archival collections created by Frank R. Rapsilber at the date of processing.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This material was received from Frank R. Rapsilber in 1967 and 1969.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
